And after these two knots let go of the skin from the incision a quantity as big as a finger: and cut off all of it roundly, and remove it from there.
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	Then dry in the lower part of the skin of the testes at the section from which runs blood and pus: as we have told in what has been preceded.
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	Then put the wool dipped in oil and place on the navel: and administer the ligature which we have described.
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	And when the sutures are taken out, apply to it a piece of white wax that we have mentioned, after incising its edge, with caution as to the flow of blood.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	For this is apt to happen many times.
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	And discharge the ligature, until it falls away by itself.
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	But if its fall is delayed, then moisten it with warm water: and place on it the piece that we have mentioned, until it falls away.
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	Then take care of the navel with the remaining cure for the wound, until it is healed.
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	[The Ramie plant]
Caput LXVI.	Chapter LVI.
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	In this ramage there was no one who dared to attempt a cure with iron.
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	And first they said that it happened as we have told about the ramage which is with the vine.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	Which is to say that the strings should be loosed after cutting over them with ease on the lower part: and then dry in the middle, and take care afterwards for opening itself up, until they fall away: and take care of the navel, according to what we have said, until it is healed.
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	[The Separation Made in the Groin]
Caput LXVII.	Chapter LVII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When rupture occurred in the groin as we have told, and an opening was made, but nothing came out of the intestines: but if anything comes down to them, it is little, and goes back again every now and then: but if prolonged for any length of time, a fissure is added to the skin, until the intestines come out into the skin.
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And this thing happened by reason of the extension of the skin in the groin as we have said.
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	Which is to say that the skin extends: and then softens, and an opening becomes apparent, and comes out.
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	And his cure is with a cautery, as has been preceded in his narration.
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	And when he is cured with iron, according to this manner: and it is so, that the sick man lies on his back between your hands.
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then dry up the place of the rupture and eminence, by section along its breadth, according to the quantity of three fingers.
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Then tighten the ligature and, which are under the skin, until when it is detected there is a white pus, that is under the skin which follows itself.
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then take a ray and put the patient on the place of eminence from the pus, and press the patient to the depth of the hand.
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then cover the two places of eminence on the end of the ray from the pus with a stitch, connecting one to the other: then remove the end of the ray.
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not injure the ligature at all, nor stretch one nor any other, as I told you to know in the cure of the intestinal branch.
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then this cure for the wound.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	When you cut the fillet, clean it out, and restore the bone, until it is hardened.
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	For the stitch holds fast, and eminence of the rupture is not added.
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And the cautery is better in this place: for it is closer to salvation.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	As regards the softening of the skin of the testes, there are three methods: first, by being dipped in hot water; second, by the application of hot plasters; third, by being rubbed with a hot cloth.
Caput LXVIII.	Head XXVIII.
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	The skin of the testes is often softened in some men, because the flesh between them becomes soft, and they acquire an attractive appearance.
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary for him who is asked to cure himself, that he lie on his back, and that he cover the whole soft skin which has been softened over the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	Then he will join the two lips together with a stitch: and if there is a need for it, in the first place three stitches of the softened skin, or four, and a firm stitch.
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then incision between sutures.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	Then care for the cure of the remaining wounds, until they are healed, and let the sutures fall off.
¶ De Castratione.	§ On Castration.
Caput LXIX.	Chapter LIX.
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	You should know that castration is an excommunication in our law: and for that reason it would be fitting for me to forget about it in this book of mine: and its reminder is not necessary, except for two reasons.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	One is that it should be in the knowledge of a physician when he is questioned about it: and so that he may know how to cure him who has it.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And the other mode is that we often have needed castration in some of our animals, for their benefits, such as rams, horses, and cats, and similar kinds of animals.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I therefore say that castration is done according to two modes.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by rubbing.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by a slits and cuts.
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	But in that which is done by rubbing, the course of the operation is this: that we should make the animal sit in hot water, until his testicles become soft and slack, and hang down: then we should cut them off with our hands, until they are completely gone and do not appear under the touch.
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	But in castration by slit and cut, it is necessary that you hold the animal, and with your left hand press the skin of his testicles.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then bind the suspensory, and dry on all of the one cut, until when they come out two testes: then cut it after you have scalded them both, and do not leave on them any cloth of a kind of suture, which is over the skin.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this mode of castration is better than that which is done by rubbing: because by rubbing perhaps some remains of the testicles are left behind, so that the animal desires to have coitus.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound, until it heals.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	§ On the Curing of Hermaphrodites in Two Ways.
Caput LXX.	Chapter LXVII.
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	A hermaphrodite is from the testicles according to two ways.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	The sperm of these is, for it seems that there is a space, or the skin of the testicles, in that it is between two testicles, figure like a small woman, in which are hairs: and sometimes when it runs urine from him who is in the skin of the testicles.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	But in women there is one kind, and it is a small woman over the skeleton like a testicle of a man, emerging towards the outside: of which one is like a penis of a man, and two like two testicles.
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	And the treatment of the three kinds, two from the testes, and one from a woman, is this: for you must break down the added flesh, until you remove the impression of them.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then take care of these with the remaining wounds.
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	But as for the second kind of men, from which urine flows out, which is on the skin of the testes, there is no operation, nor is there any treatment at all.
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	As for the incising of the scrotum and the flesh emerging in women.
Caput LXXI.	Chapter LXXI.
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	The tentigon should be added strongly to the natural thing until it is satisfied and becomes ugly in appearance: and sometimes it grows great in some women, so that it spreads out like a penis, and reaches up to coitus.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	You should therefore hold the tentigon with your hand, or with a hook, and cut it off: and you must not at all go into the incision, especially in the deep root: so that blood does not flow.
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of this wound with the treatment, until it heals.
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	But as for the middle flesh, it is the flesh that is born in the womb of the mother, until it fills it up: and perhaps it flows out to the outside according to the resemblance of the tail: and because of this they call certain disease tailed.
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	You should therefore cut it off as you cut off the tentigon, and take care of it until it heals.
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	On the Care of the Utero (womb), which is not pierced.
Caput LXXII.	De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	(The treatment of the uterus, which is not pierced, or the foramen ovale.)
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	(And it is either natural or accidental.)
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	(Accidental is from an illness that precedes it; and the same [illness] may have come about either from flesh that has been added to it, or from a fine spitting, or from a lump: and it may have taken place in the depths of the womb, or in its sides, or in its upper part, or in its lower part; and it prohibits coitus and impregnation, and giving birth, and perhaps menstruation.)
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	(And the knowledge of it is acquired by the examination of midwives, if the accumulation is evident near at hand.)
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	(If it is not evident, then seek it with your fingers or a lamp.)
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	(If there is an accumulation of fine spittle between the two lips, then bring it closer and remove it.)
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	(And it is, as you place a handful of cotton wool on the two lips.)
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	(Then place your fingers from both hands together, and the woman should lie on her back with spread legs.)
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	(Then stretch the two lips with force, until the fine spittle is removed, and the accumulation opens up.)
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	(Then take a piece of wool, and soak it in oil, and place it on the spot; and let the woman eat it every day so that the spot does not stick.)
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	(If the spittle is thick and sticky, then you must separate it with a wide leaf of mint.)
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	(If the accumulation is flesh that has been born, then suspend it with a hook and cut it: and have with you medicines that stop the flow of blood without causing pain, such as acacia and dragon's blood, and such agate with albuginous lead.)
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	(Then insert a large silver tube so that the wound does not heal quickly, hold it for several days; and administer lion's mane dried, then treat the rest with the usual treatment until it heals.)
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	And sometimes when I am born from the womb, the birth of the flesh of others: it is necessary then that they be struck according to this mode: because there is no opposition with iron at all, while there is an apostema of cancerous, since there is a cancer in the womb.
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	On the treatment of hemorrhoids, Athahelil, and botry rubeae in women's wombs.
Caput LXXIII.	Chapter LIII. On the treatment of hemorrhoids, Athahelil, and botry rubeae (bloody rash) in women's wombs.
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	Hemorrhoids are an opening of the venous orifices, until they bleed profusely regularly.
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	When then are treated these hemorrhoids, they become thori; and I have already spoken in the division of their kinds, and of their signs: and here I will speak of those which receive cure, and of those which do not.
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	I say, then, that the hemorrhoids which are in the opening of the womb, and do not appear to have any sense: then there is no cure for them with iron.
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	But which from these hemorrhoids are in the opening of the womb above where the sense falls, they are those which are cured.
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	It is necessary then that you enter the woman into a cold house.
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	Then extend Athahelil with forceps, or with a rough cloth, and cut them from their roots.
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	Then dust on them near the flow of blood from one cut with a powder without mordient; as acacia, and dragon's blood, and thorns, and such like to them.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	Then push his feet against the wall at an hour.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	Then put her into a cold water.
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	If the bleeding persiste: then let her sit in a decoction of sommach, and of corn-meal, and of gall, and such like.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	Then take wheat flour, and make it into a paste with honey and vinegar, and make a plaster with it on her back.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	But if the blood is separated from it, then it is good: but if not, then make adhere to her back furrows, and nettle-sores, without scarification.
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take a piece of cloth and dip it in taraxacum juice, or in arnglosa's juice, or in the sap of the boughs of alnet trees, that is to say, in Pontic wine, and make it adhere to the leech.
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When the poultice has cooled down, then take care of the place with the ointment, until it has healed.
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	Albarth is really similar to taraxacum in shape and is rough in appearance.
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It must therefore be that you make it appear from it, according to what I have said in the illustration, equally: and take care of it, until it has healed.
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	Regarding the Output Wound That Occurs in the Uterine Cavity.
Caput LXXIIII.	Chapter LXXIV.
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	Various poultices occur in the womb, such as cancer, and hard poultices, ulcers, blisters, scabs, and frostbitten flesh, that is to say, herpes, coldness, fistulae, hemorroids, warts, and burns.
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And I have already said concerning all these diseases and their kinds, and their signs, and their cures, in a division: it is necessary for me to speak in this book about the hot poultice that occurs in the womb, when it is from poultices that collect blood, and how to know its opening with iron.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is necessary, therefore, that you consider.
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	Then if the pain of the poultice in its beginning is sharp with its percussion and flame and fever: and you see it red: if it falls on top of it, then do not like its perforation: and take care of it with that which pleases it over maturation, until such time as it has calmed down.
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	Then it is necessary that you make the woman sit on a chair that she can reach by two seats, and lie down, or lean back, and gather her feet toward the lower side of the femur: and let her hips be expanded, and put her arms under her knees, and bind each with a suitable ligature.
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then the midwife should sit down on the right side of the bed, and administer the instrument with which she opens the maternal womb.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	Whose form came in those who are behind.
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And it is necessary that when you administer this instrument, you make the womb smooth with the radius of its depth: so that it does not enter by means of the instrument more than the depth of the womb, and hurts the sick.
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	But if the instrument is more than the depth of the womb, then it is necessary that you should put a padding on top of the depth of the womb: so that you prevent the entrance of the whole instrument into the depth of the womb: and it is necessary that you should put a turner, which runs in the instrument, from the upper side: and that he holds the instrument, and that he turns the turner, until the depth of the womb has opened.
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	When it therefore appears and is touched by hand, and is soft and smooth: then you should separate it from the head with a cotton wad.
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	When it therefore drains the pus, then you should put a cotton wad soaked in rose oil: or in viride oil, in which there is some stinginess: and you should put the cotton, and pull out a piece into the depth of the womb.
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And place outside on the womb, and on the wool of the lamb dipped in water, in which there are some bubbles:
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then take care after two days with ointment that is suitable for it, until it is healed.
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	And sometimes when the womb is washed and the lamb, so that it swells with water and honey: then with water in which there are some bubbles of a radix of lily, or of long aristo: and then return to the ointment.
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	That if the lamb is hidden inside the womb, then it is necessary that you should refrain from curing it with fire: indeed take care of itself with what we have said in division.
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	Doctrines on obstetrics, how they treat the foetus according to a non-natural form of exit.
Caput Lxxu.	Chapter LXXVI
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for the obstetrician to recognize the natural puerperal condition at first.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	From the signs then, when you see a woman compressing herself towards her lower parts, and desiring to smell the air, and relishing herself when something is passing out of her, then you should know that this birth is in the natural form, and the exit of the child is over her head, and the second with it: or suspended, or hanging from her navel.
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When then you see these signs, it is necessary for the womb to compress so that the child can descend quickly.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	For when it has passed over her head, the second passes with it, and is cleansed of its excess by a good purification.
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	But if this birth is outside these times, it is unnatural, unbelievable.
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	For when the child sometimes exits with his feet first, and the body goes out before her head, and his feet and hands are one, or his hand is one or his foot alone: or when her head and hands go out, or when it turns inside out, and perhaps it turns over its neck, and similar figures that are unbelievable.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	It is therefore necessary for the obstetrician to be prudent and careful in all these things, and to beware of error and delusion: and I will show you every form, and what is the nature of it, and interpret it by that, and point out on it.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the child exits with his natural exit over her head, and it presses on her, and the birth is difficult for her, and you see its strength already weakened: then make her sit on a chair, or let the women support her: and wash her with a fennel decoction, and with wet oils.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then the obstetrician should introduce his finger between her labia, and feel for the second inside, and wipe it with his nail, until he finds what is within her from moisture: and press the womb of the woman, until the child comes out.
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	But if it has not come down, then a woman should be made to vomit with foenugraeum and oil of sesamum.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then order her to compress herself after the enema, and make her sneeze with a remedy, and hold her nose and mouth for an hour.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	For a fetus will come out immediately.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If two hands of the fetus come out first, then you should put them back in with ease gradually.
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	But if it does not obey on entering, then put the woman on a seat, and raise her feet up: then bring the seat down to the ground: and let the woman hold, so that she does not fall by the concussion.
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	But if the hands do not come out, and the fetus dies: then make an incision, and remove the residue of the fetus: and bind his hand with a cloth, and pull him out by equality: for he will come out.
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	The exit of the fetus is on its feet.
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When the fetus comes out on its feet, then you should push them up: then turn the fetus gradually: then make it even.
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then take one of his feet, and stretch it out gradually.
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	But when they have come out as far as the hips, then order her to compress herself, and make her sneeze with a remedy: for it will come out if God wills.
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	And if it does not come out with the narration that we mentioned, then you should gradually reduce the fetus, until you put it back in its natural form.
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	For he will come out then with ease of exit.
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	But if it is prohibited to do all that we mentioned above: then take foenugraeum and oil of sesamum, and gum arabicum: and pound it all together in a mortar with a good pounding: then mix the entire thing with the woman's urine, and insert it into her lower belly.
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then make her sit in warm water until she becomes hypersentive.
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	And so when you see that his lower parts are already warmed, then put myrrh on him and bear him.
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When the wound has been held for an hour, then make her sit on a chair.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then make her sneeze: and tighten his mouth and nose: and press the lower leg with light compression.
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the fire will come out immediately.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	Exit the fetus on to the knees and hands.
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When it has come out in this form, then insert your hands slowly.
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman will lie on her neck, and her feet will hang down to the lower parts: and she will lie on a bed, and cross her hands.
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	Then press on her belly slowly.
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	Then pull out what is under her feet from the pubic area, until she is prepared in the lower part.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If the fetus does not come out, then take her feet, and move them with a rapid motion.
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then press on what is above the navel slowly, until the fetus rises to the upper parts.
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then insert your hands, and make the fetus even slower: and instruct the woman to contract, until the fetus comes out.
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	Exit the fetus hanging downward from the arms.
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	The hands are tight.
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	But if she cannot be reduced, then wash the woman, and make her walk.
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	But if walking is also impossible, then make her lie on a bed: and strike her thighs with a rapid motion.
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then administer the lubricant you have prepared from mucus.
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If she takes it (the lubricant), then make her sit on a chair.
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then study the hands for reduction, and make the fetus adopt a natural shape: and instruct the woman to sneeze, and tell her to contract herself, until she comes out.
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	Exit the fetus on to her neck, with spread arms, and her face is toward the back of her mother's body.
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	It is fitting that the midwife should hold the fetus in her hand, and then rotate it little by little, and equitably with ease.
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	When, however, it has been brought into equilibrio, then place it on the hollow of her hand that we spoke of before, covered with oil and mucus.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then command her to move it little by little.
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	When you have done this, then cause her to sit down on a seat, and command her to lean to the right side.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then command her to compress it: and cause her to sneeze with condensed air.
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	The exit of the fetus prepared on the side.
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When it descended to the opening of the mother's womb in this manner with the second touch, then cut the second touch with your nail, until it is discharged from the moisture.
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	But if he should be suspended on the surface of the fetus and its neck, then cut him from the navel: lest he should be retained, and die.
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then push the fetus into the inside, until you put it in the right place: and command the woman to compress herself at times: for he himself shall come out by the exit easily.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	The exit of twins, or of a multitude of fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	You should know that twins are often born: and sometimes three, and four.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	But this is strange, and seldom happens.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	But five is a thing outside nature, and do not live long: and they hold them, though they multiply, second by second: and separate them with a scissor, distinguishing between them the ligature in the navel of each one.
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	And sometimes they go out like a single fetus going out by natural exit, easily: and they go out by a loud exit, as we have described.
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	That if any of them should be difficult at the birth, and they reach that which we spoke of out of natural figures, then take care of them as we have spoken: and let her lie on a soft bed, and let her do what she does easily and slowly, and dispose herself according to every figure with him who prepares her, leading her to salvation.
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	When one is formed in the womb from an embryo, and aborts: sometimes it forms one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, and more than ten: but I have found that a woman when she aborts, sends out seven, and another fifteen, all formed.
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	That which is done by the glorious sage in measurement.
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	This therefore needs to be in the knowledge of obstetrics.
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	Perhaps indeed it will come to that like it: oppose therefore to him what is necessary
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	On the extraction of a dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter LVII on the head.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you are troubled about the fetus that is dead along with what I said in the division on medication, and does not come out, and urge to use the operation by hand, then you should consider.
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	But if the woman is of sound virtue, and is not with any of the accidents from which she fears destruction: then it is necessary that she should lie down on a bed, on her back, and should have her head turned downward, and her legs raised: and the minister should hold her by two parts, or bind her to the bed, so that her body is not taken out with the extraction of the fetus.
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then moisten the mouth of the womb with wet oil with mucilage of aloe, and fenugreek, and linseed.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	Then let the obstetrics wash her hand with these oils and mucilages: then let her enter the womb with ease.
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	Then she should ask where to place the hook from the fetus, and places convenient for that.
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Consider therefore, then if the fetus is prepared to come down on the head: then fix the hooks in her eyes, or in her neck, or in her mouth, or in her palate, or under her beard, or in her throat, or in places convenient for that. Consider that it is necessary that the hook be fixed somewhere, so that she does not come out.
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	But if the descent is over his feet, then in the chest, and over his ribs with the middle.
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	And it should be that he holds the hook with his right hand: and he lays his left hand on himself where it is between the fingers: and he inserts it with his hand smoothly, and fastens the hook in some of those places that we said, until he has completed the incision.
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	Then he should fasten the other hook or a third, if he is able to: so that there is an equality of contraction, and it does not decline on one side.
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	Then it should be extended with an equal extension, and not only a length along the straight line, but also move on all sides, so that it eases its exit: as happens when the tooth is removed during its erosion.
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	And it should be in that place where it is between that, so that the extension softens.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	That if a part of it is retained from that, then the Midwife should put some fingers with oil: and insert them from one side, so that they turn with it what is held back.
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	But if a part of the baby leaves, then the hooks should be moved to another place that is higher: do this until the whole baby has left.
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	But if a hand leaves before the other, and it is not possible to reduce it due to its constriction: then it should be covered with cloth.
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	Then remove it until all of it has left, and cut it off or at the plant, or on the bed: and so you should do in the other hand and in both feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	But if the baby's head is large, or a constriction has occurred during its exit, or water has accumulated in its head: then it should be inserted between the fingers of the Spatumile spike that grows: and he should find with it, and remove the water: or he should cut it off with an instrument called Almisdac: whose shape comes with the shapes of the other instruments in the chapter after this.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then he should separate the skin with pincers, just as we have said above. Afterward, he should remove the bones with forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	If the head has come out and is held by the fork: then seek to find, until the moisture that is in the chest is discharged.
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	If it is not complicated and does not comply with delivery: then you should make an incision on the head suddenly, according to what is possible for you.
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	If the lower limb is swollen or there is hydrops in it, then you should make a cut in it, until the moisture that is in it has drained.
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	But if the fetus is above the feet, then its attraction is easy, and its direction to the mother's mouth is gentle.
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	If it is held by the windpipe or the chest, then you should remove it with the cloth that you have wrapped around your hand: and seek to find the windpipe or chest, until what is in them has drained.
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	If other limbs are removed, and then the head returns: then the midwife should insert her left hand.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	If then the mother' s mouth is open, then the midwife should insert her hand into the depth of the uterus, and seek the head, and attract it with her fingers up to the mouth: then she should insert one hook or two hooks, and attract it with them.
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	If the mother' s mouth is held back, because of the warm apoplexy that has happened to her: then it is not necessary for her to work on the head, but rather at that time it is necessary to administer an infusion of wet and greasy things: and to administer plaster: and to sit in water that softens and moisten.
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	If the fetus is above its side, then it is possible to adjust it: then administer what we have said above about the single-foaled cow.
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If it is not possible to do this, then incise hastily and remove it.
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And it is necessary that you do not leave anything inside at all after the second day.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When therefore you have completed your operation, then administer what we said in the aphorisms concerning the hot poultices which happen in the wombs.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If blood should flow, then let him descend into the waters of styptic powder, and administer the remaining cure.
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And I have already seen a woman, in whom the fetus was dead: then she was impregnated on top of it with another viscrum, and after that another dead fetus was formed.
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	Then happened to her after a long time an aphorism in the navel of her, and it was swollen, until it was opened: and she began to emit pus.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I was called to her cure, and I treated her for a long time: but the wound did not heal.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	So I placed over it some strong plasters of attraction: and she came out of the place of the opening.
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Then passed a few days, and came out another opening.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	I was therefore surprised from there, when there is no opening in the womb.
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	I considered, that there were bones of a dead fetus.
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I therefore questioned the wound, and removed many bones, with a woman who was in better condition of her health: and now she no longer lived so long a time, and sent out from the place little pus.
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	And I do not consider this an extraordinary thing, unless there is knowledge and help for it, which the healing artist gives with his hand from the cure.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	Of Forms Of Instruments Necessary In The Extraction Of The Fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	Head LXVII.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	Here is the form of the Strigulator, which are made equal to the books, and to which two twists are attached to the two ends of two pieces of wood.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	However, this Vertigo should be made less stiff than the strigulator: and to make it so, either of ebony, or of wood of bos.
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	And the breadth of each of the two limbs is as broad as two fingers; and the border of each limb is as broad as a finger; and the length of each of them is a palm and a half and a half; and in the middle of the two limbs there are two additions of the same kind of wood, which have already been fixed on both, whose breadth is a half-palm and more a little; and the breadth of each is as broad as two fingers or less.
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	And these two additions enter into the mouth of the womb, so that it opens with them when you rotate the two spirals.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	Form of the womb which is opened by the two spirals.
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	Other form similar to its, but thinner and lighter.
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	Let it be made of ebony wood, or of cherry, according to the similarity of the forceps.
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	However, in the extreme part of it there are two additions, as you see here above: and the length of each of these additions is as broad as a palm; and the breadth of each is as broad as two fingers.
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	When you open the womb with it, then make the woman sit on a bed, hanging her feet from its sides, and
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	Then introduce these two additions joined together into the womb: and you holding the extreme part of the instrument between her hips.
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument as you do with the forceps, equally according to the quantity which you wish from the opening of the womb's mouth, until the Obstetrix does what he wants.
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	Form of the other spiral than that which said the ancient, as it is forced and driven the fetus.
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	Form of the camel, from whose head comes out the great hump; and is like the forceps, which has teeth at its extreme part, as you see it.
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	And when it is made round, like the forceps in this form, as you see, which has teeth like a saw, so that it cuts and crushes.
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	Form of the camel, from whose head comes out the small hump.
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	Form A in the hand hold one nail.
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	Form A in the hand hold two nails.
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	The forceps which has cutting teeth and with which the head of the fetus is pulled out.
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	Form A scalpel having two ends to cut off the head.
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	Form A two scalpels also holding them in your hands.
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	These instruments are all used, and the more they multiply in their species, and are prepared by the craftsman's hands, the faster they perform their work, and the higher among men because of their number.
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	Therefore do not despise any of these instruments, but rather know that it is prepared for you.
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	It is unjustifiable, however, the need for them.
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	Regarding the extraction of the second part.
Caput LXXVIII.	Head 78.
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When the second part is retained at birth, then you should take the weak one, so that it holds its breath.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then let her sneeze with conditioning: and tightly hold your hand on her nose, and the nostrils of her.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If so then she comes out through this, it is good.
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not: then take a stick, and pierce into the cover hole: and put in it herbs opening the mouth of the mother, such as calamus, Rutum, Anetum, Chamomilla, Sesamum, Cassiam linum, and Centauroxylon: take all of these herbs, or some of them, and mix them with water, and put them on fire.
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then place a arrow in the hole of the cover of the pot, and another end in the mother's mouth: and let her hold it until the vapor comes to maturity of the mother.
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then let her sneeze, as we have said.
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	The second part will come out with ease.
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	If it remains after this care, and does not come out: then instruct the midwife to dip her hand in sesame oil, or mucilaginous aloe.
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then he inserted himself into her vagina, and asked her if she was the second one.
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	When he had found her, then he took her, and stretched her out little by little.
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	But if it [the baby] is attached in the deep part of the womb, then he should insert his hand, according to what we have said above, until he finds the second one, and pulls her out little by little according to the straightness, so that the womb does not break because of a sudden pull: it should be turned over with ease towards the right and left: then add [the quantity] of the pull.
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	But she obeys then, and is pulled out, and is separated from the adhesion.
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	That if the opening of the womb is constricted, as we have already told: be careful with it during a sneeze, and clean the opening of the womb with herbs after the delivery.
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	But if she does not come out with all that we have mentioned above, then be careful not to tire yourself out by insisting on the extraction.
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	But it is necessary that when she comes out from the opening of the womb, there are some tied around the waist of the woman.
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then purify her with a tetrapharmacone ointment.
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	But this one will make her rot and dissolve after a few days, and she will come out.
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	However, when it begins to rot, an evil smell comes out from her towards the stomach and head, and it causes a bad illness.
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	Therefore, it is necessary that appropriate suffumigations are administered to it.
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	However, there are some ancient ones who have already experienced the suffumigations of mustard and dried figs.
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	The form of the instrument with which the woman is suffumed while retaining the second one and during the menstruation.
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	Let it be made from wheat like ash or barley and placed over fire; the suffumigation should be placed on plums; hold it, until that suffumigation is consumed; and then take another one.
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	Regarding the treatment of the ano without perforation.
Caput LXXIX.	Chapter LXXIX.
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	Many boys are born, and their hams are not yet pierced, which has already been cut by the subtle sifac.
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	Therefore, the midwife should pierce that sifac with her finger; and if she does not, she should pierce it herself with a sharp spatemil: and let her take care not to touch it.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then put over it wool dipped in wine and oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound with ointment, until it heals.
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	But if you suspect that it has been infected, then put a lead pipe in the hole for several days, and remove it when the boy feels like defecating.
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And already the boys have become ill because of the infection from the consolidation of the wound, or the formation of pus.
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	Therefore, let that consolidation be removed, and then be cured with it as we have said in the treatment with oil and lead.
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	The Treatment of Fistulas which occur in the lower parts.
Caput LXXX.	Chapter LXVIII.
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	The Fistulas which occur in the lower parts are a kind of nodulation and grossness which occurs near the anus: or in a space between one part: and there is one fistula, or several.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	But when that nodulation is dried up, it opens, and from it runs out a watery white discharge, or a subtle pus.
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And sometimes from these fistulas pass through them.
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	Therefore the penetrating ones are known by that which comes out from defecation, and windiness, when a sick person uses it for defecation: and perhaps it comes out from them in a state of sickness.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	And there are fistulas when they penetrate into the space up to the ischial bone, and up to the muscle of the thigh.
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And there are fistulas which penetrate up to the joint of the hip, and up to a nodule at the tail end.
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	But from that which is known as a penetrating fistula up to an organ, and also not a penetrating one, it is, when you put your finger of the index into an organ: and when you put in it a subtle sharp instrument made of brass or iron: provided there is no tortuosity.
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	If there is a twist in it, then insert into it trying from thin lead, or a needle from the hair, until you feel trying, or a needle in your finger.
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	If you do not feel it well, and there is no discharge, no wind, no dryness as I have said: then you will know that it is not penetrating: therefore go on to the cure.
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	And when the fistula penetrate to dryness, or to the meatus of urine: then the meaning of it is the exit of urine from it, and its prohibition from this so that the place with medicines hardens.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	But if it penetrate to the joint of the hip, or to the mouth of the hip: then the sign of it is that it should reach trying to that place, if there is no twist in it up to the mouth: and the finding of pain on the side, and that it is discharged pus from it always: and that it does not scabs in it with ointment, and hardens.
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	And in these all-penetrating fistulas there is no cure at all: and the cure of them is work and uselessness to it from foolish doctors, over whom a form is made.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	But in that which is not penetrating, and is not old, there is hope of cure with a bandage: for I tell you, and have proven it: and it is, so that the sick man lies between your hands on his back: and you cleanse the hairs of its legs all the way up to its hips, and its hips are bent towards its belly.
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then insert-ing lead, or air, if there is a twist in the fistula, until you know where it reaches.
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	But if he feels it on a certain part, then you should put your finger-tip on the part.
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	But if you feel in your finger-tip that it has already penetrated through itself on its own, by way of feeling between your finger and the skin, or flesh: then you know certainly that it is penetrating: so do not work in it, for its cure is not with it, as we have said.
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	They said that he heals certain men of disease by means of a subtle caustic fire applied according to the width of the fistula as described above, and by introducing this fire into the fistula until it reaches a particular place.
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Then repeat that twice or three times until you are sure that all the added filtered flesh, which is like a feather of an owl, has dried up.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Then treat that with liniment in butter until the flesh comes off, which has dried up: then treat it with an ointment that generates flesh and hardens it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If he is healed, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	And if not, then he will never be healed with any other treatment.
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	And if he emerges with the wound and does not reach as far as your finger, which is in the anus, and there is between it and the tent a thick flesh or sear: and you will see a fistula running along the surface of the skin, then dry off the skin from the beginning of the fistula, and dry out with the tent what is in the fistula until it reaches where the end of the tent has reached, and the tent comes out and falls.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Then clean those filtered flesh, which are like a feather of an owl, so that nothing remains of them.
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	But if he conquers you with blood, and dissolves between you and your operation as he severs those flesh: then it is better that it should be so, and faster in healing, cauterize it with fire, or with sharp medication.
Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	For the caustic with fire brings good habits together, it dries up the flesh added, and stops the flow of blood, and dries out the moisture.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	Then treat that with liniment in butter, or powdered herbs, until the place releases puss, and the added flesh comes off in puss.
Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	Then treat that with an ointment that hardens and generates flesh, until it becomes tough: and there are medications that have stifness and drying out.
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	When I am hungry, then I eat; and when I am full, then I stop eating.
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	But if the fistula has reached the depth of the hip and has elongated beyond the confines of the body: then insert your finger into the abdomen and feel it.
Si ergo sentis tentam, et inter te, et inter eam est uelamen ex sifac, aut carne, et est propinqua penetrationi: tunc non est operatio in illo, nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	But if you feel that there is a defect between you and it, and the defect is of the skin or meat, and is near penetration: then the operation on him should not be done, unless by means of trust and hope.
Quod est, quia administratur in eo unus trium modorum: aut ut cauterizes ipsam, sicut diximus: aut seces eam, donec consequaris concauitatem eius, ut sit possibile tibi intromittere licinia, et curationem ex proximo.	That is, because it has two ways of being treated: either as you cauterize it, as we have said; or cut it off, until you get the desired result, so that you can put a hook in it, and cure from nearby.
Et non procedas multum cum sectione, ut non incidas lacertum continentem anum, et accidat super infirmum exitus egestionis absque uoluntate.	And do not proceed much with the cut, lest you fall on a snake that is keeping something in check, and an accident happens to the exit of the body without wanting it.
Deinde cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then the care for that with him which we have said.
Fortasse enim sanabitur: aut elonges ipsum uelamen, et mundes ipsum postquam secas ipsum usque prope anum, sicut diximus, aut cum tenta, aut cum instrumento alio acutae extremitatis.	Perhaps he will be healed: or he will lengthen the defect, and wash it thoroughly near the hip, as we have said, or with a hook, or with another sharp instrument.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	Then clean those filthy meats that are in the cut, until you can examine them.
Deinde conare restaurationem uulneris totius cum sectione, et orificio superiore ubi consolidatur: et remanet Fistula aperta in interiore parte anus, et erit leuius super infirmum.	Then try to heal the wound of all the cut, and repair the hole from which the meat has come out: and there remains an open fistula in the inner part of the anus, and will be looser than the previous one.
Et quandoque suitur Fistula secundum hunc modum: et est, quando intromittis tentam in Fistulam: et est in latere ani circa superficiem corporis cum cute et margine ani: tunc accipe tentam perforatae extremitatis, quae est sicut acus aleskef, id est, praeparantium coria, secundum hanc formam.	And when this fistula follows this way: and it is when you insert your finger into the fistula: and it is in the back of the hip near the surface of the body with skin and margin of the hip: then take the sharp end of the hook-shaped thing, which is like a needle-thread, according to this form.
Et intromitte in eam filum inuolutum ex quinque filis, et circiter ea.	And insert into it the string wound up into five turns, and around it.
Deinde intromitte tentam cum filo in Fistulam, donec consequatur concauitatem eius.	Then insert your finger with the thread into the fistula, until you get the desired result of it.
Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If then there is a piercing into the margin of the anus internally near by, then remove the filament from that hole: so that you can insert your finger in an anum, and remove the end of the filament, and join both ends together: and tighten each one well, and let go of it on the same day or two days: and to the extent that the filament pierces into the flesh, tighten it well until those tissues which are between the two ends of the filament fall down, and then care for the wound, until it heals and consolidates.
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	If, however, the orifice of the fistula is not piercing: then make it pierce wherever you prepare it for yourself, unless it be in a deep place.
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	For it is not good for you to make it pierce because of the snake, so that you do not hit yourself with it.
