Then I detected again on top of the bone, and I did not cease to strike the bone little by little, and to try to restore it: and it was not restored until I struck out of the bone near the palm, and I took it out with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with medicine, and it was quickly consolidated, and healed; and this iteration in its operation, and cutting, was not necessary unless for the weakness of the nurse, and her lack of tolerance, and my fear of it from death: for it happened to him at all times from a bad syncope of discharge.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	The patient is therefore completely healed: and the new bone has grown in place, and his body has been made sound, and his strength has returned; and he has recovered in his powers: and he has recovered in his dispositions: and he has not done him any harm in walking at all.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the jaw is broken in a place in the body where it has already been broken: then it should be fixed, in this way: that you take a ligament, and tie it tightly at the end of the bone; and command someone who will stretch it upwards: and put another ligament, from a coarse wool, after the first one.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind the bone over the flesh, which is between the bones: and extend its end so that you can pull the flesh down towards the bottom: and you cover the flesh over the place where you want to fix it, so as not to hurt the flesh when you cut it.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a piece of wood or a board under the bone below: because when you do that, the flesh is not hurt, if you don't cut it.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it should be fixed over the corrupted place a little, so that there is no concern about the bone's corruption; and it does not appear in its appearance to the sense, and compels his own fixing force by means of another ligature.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	Which if the bone is corrupted and is not prominent, but continues with a part of it: and corruption is in its middle, or in one of its parts: then you cover all the flesh from all the parts.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place a piece of wood below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then fix that from the first part where there is corruption, until it continues with a fixing force from the other part: and let the fixing force be a little longer according to what we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	Which if corruption is in a joint, then cut that joint which is corrupted, and fix the bone where it continues from the other part.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if corruption is in the continuation of two joints: then there is no power there except for a cut.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	Which if corruption is in the hand's palm, or in the foot's sole: then the matter is difficult and hard.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter apareat tibi.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And after that, you should cut off the part and clean it up in whatever way is possible for you and adjust it with the right tool: when it does not create a contrary vein or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And you should know that there are many chisels and saws to cut these bones, according to the arrangement of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness, and subtlety, and size, and smoothness, and hardness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore, you should prepare the right tool for every type of surgery that suits that operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations require a long study with the instrument you are holding when performing them.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of these methods of the art is a witness to the methods of diseases: for then you will already find out through yourself what suits him from tools for any disease.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you at the end of this chapter the number of tools, which are given as examples of what to cut, and a proof of what you have experienced on other things.
Forma Serrae.	The shape of the saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of a different saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of another saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of the saw is drawn, but not very accurately made.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let the bow of his back be made from steel: and his handle from birch, and his shape a little off-center.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The shape of the rasp is joined.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this rasp be in the form of a star-shaped claw: and its points be in the form of star-shaped dots.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not suit unless you rub it with the heads of rasps when they are worn out, or a wide and large mouth, and is great.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The shape of a larger rasp.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The shape of a medium rasp.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The shape of a broad rasp.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The shape of a raspberry that is closed up.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Form of a sharp razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Form of the curved end of a sharp razor.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Form of a thin, sharp razor blade.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Form of a razor used to cut bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Form of a large, sharp razor.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to a file, and the end is like an axe: it is shown in many places in the dissection of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Form of a razor that fits close to its cut which has been made through bone.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	The end of it is triangular, and its ends are acute.
Fit ex Indi.	Fit from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And likewise it should be, that all which we have said of razors, and of chisels, and of saws, may be.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	Of the incisions on the ends, and of the fitting of the bones with saws.
Caput LXXXIX.	Head LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The ends putrifie, either by an external cause, or an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	But when you have cured it with medicine, and there is no cure; and you see corruption coming to a limb, where it does not affect anything: then you should cut that limb all the way to where the corruption comes in, so that the sick one may be cured of his malady which is greater than the defect of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of what happens to that is, that the limb becomes discolored, until it is cured: for if fire burns it, or putrefaction comes after corruption: until corruption enters into that which follows that limb, and spreads through all the body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Then it is proper to cut the limb with care, and in like manner if the cause of corruption is from an external impact from some of the venenous ones: such as the sea scorpion, the bee, the nettle, and others similar to them.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	But if corruption or an impact is on the end of a finger, then cut that finger, and do not leave space for corruption, so that it may go all the way to the other hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And likewise if it has happened in the hand, then cut that hand from the root of a sharp axe, and do not leave space for corruption, until it reaches the length of a short arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if you have penetrated into it, then cut the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if corruption has already taken hold, and you see it all around the elbow: then death is upon that limb.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And apart from this cure, a certain amount of strength is required.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And likewise do for the foot, when corruption has penetrated into a toe, then cut it at the joint: and if it enters the shin, then cut the whole leg.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	That if corruption has already reached above the knee, there is no hope of recovery, except for amputation and surrender to death by leaving it to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the way to cut the limb off, or to sever it is, when you want to tighten the ligaments lower down, which you want to cut: and tighten another ligament above the spot.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And stretch out one minister's ligament downward: and stretch out another minister's ligament upward.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments with your spatulum, until all the bone is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut it, or sever it.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And you should place a linen cloth over all parts, so that the saw does not touch the sound bone: and it happens to the sick with added poultice and warm plasters.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if blood flows inward while you are working, then cauterize the spot quickly: or put some powder on it to stop the flow of blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your own medication, until it is finished.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable ligament, and take care of it, until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I will tell you what happened to the man in his foot, this same thing that I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happened in his black foot, with the heat that is like the burning of fire: and that corruption first began in a toe, until it covered the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the surgeon took a knife from its case, after he saw corruption come upon the member with its movement, which he found out from pain and its warmth; and he cut it himself at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, that same corruption happened to him again in his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	Then he came to me, and I tried to restore that excess with him when I put on his hand from the medicines after purifying his body: and the excess did not respond, and it began to heal in another finger: until the corruption began in his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	So he called me to cut his hand: but I did not want to do so, hoping from myself for a response to that excess: and I was also afraid of death at the cutting of his hand by incision.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the power of the finger was above death.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	And after he had despaired of me, he turned back to his land: and he came to me about it, because he hoped, and he cut off all his hand: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this account except to be an aid against that which falls from the kind of this disease: and to be a sign what signifies, and according to what is concerned.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the treatment of gangrenous wounds, and the quality of cauterization with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 100.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When a gangrene happens in some fleshy member, and the space of the gangrene is prolonged, until it does collect blood: then it breaks, or pierces, and what is in it comes out, and there remains a hollow place like a wound, and the skin over it is like thin cloth: and it does not come to its last corruption, nor impresses into the bone, nor the nerves, nor the ligaments: it deserves to be called a Sinus: but it is not called a Fistula: nevertheless if it prolongs its space, until it impresses the corruption in some of these members, then it is called a Fistula, or a zak-o-kain.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the cure is such that you strike off all of the skin like a wrapper; and above all when it has become thin, and made like a blanket; and put trust in it because it would not adhere to the place, for its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere, and does not result from it that corruption: and if there is a thickness of flesh, then the cure itself with Cantharis: and is, as you consider to the sinew.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is great, and the pus that is discharged from it is foul-smelling: then cantharis itself with a medicinal substance, which is vinegar, oil, and saffron, parts receiving equal portions, mixed together in a vessel: and boiled on fire, until it turns red: and comes to a thickness of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and cantharis with it to the sinew: and tighten the opening of it, and let the medicine into it for a period of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with an expression: make it for days, until the sinew is cleared away, and the smell is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when cantharis is made with water of ash, when this medicine is not present with you: and is, that you take ash from wood of oak, or ash from oak-tree: and pour it on water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then strain it, and cantharis with it, until you put trust in that the sinew is now washed away.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	That if the tolerance for the Egyptian medicine is not strong, nor for water of ash, then cantharis itself with water and honey, which has already been mixed with crushed saffron.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or cantharis itself with honey and wine, mixed, for the property of honey is to purify, and to wash away: and wine makes the sinew adhere, especially when there is an abundance of astringency and dryness in it.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	How often do you perform this operation and trust that the sinus is now healed: then clean him out with a syringe as he performs the operation to give birth to flesh in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And so that you may receive the embalming paste: and dissolve him with rose oil, and with wine astringent: or clean him out with certain medicines, and with other ointments, whose properties I have written in the book of ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	That if the opening of the sinus is narrow, in which the syringe does not enter: then widen it slightly with a bit of iron: or put in it licorice soaked in Egyptian ointment, or in basilicon ointment, until it widens.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And likewise if the opening is also wide, then join the lips together with a stitch: and let go from it a quantity in which the syringe enters without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And likewise if the opening from which there runs pus is elevated towards the top: then dry it out in a lower place that is in it so that the pus runs down from it: for when pus is confined in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from being born in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	That if you are not able to dry out the sinus all around its lower part according to what you wish: then try to prepare the member in such a way that the pus runs from it easily according to how you prepare it for yourself.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Consider that you do not retain anything of the pus at all in it: and take medicines that are used to put on the spot, fitting for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And have such a quantity of the cloth so that it communicates with all of the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps into the direct opening of the sinus hole, making a slightly larger opening of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from the ointment a thin cloth over another cloth according to the quantity of the hole: and place it on the member at a distant position from the opening of the sinus so that the exit of pus from it is aided: and do not remove the large cloth, unless after a few days.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	And yet he who is super orificium sinus, is he whom you move at all times, so that he goes out what is gathered in him from pus: and know ye, that the virus which runs out of it, is much, or little: or digested, or indigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when ye consider again the place of the sinus itself, do ye not see that the lord feels pain in it, or is there no pain in it? and is there an apostema or not?
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment extends thus far, and ye see the matter which runs out on the orifice of the sinus, then know that the sinus is already attached, or approaches to attachment: then therefore dissolve it in the morning, or in the third day: and when ye dissolve the wound, then change the cloth, and renew the unguent.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if the virus runs out of the sinus after a long space of time, then do not despair concerning its attachment, because its healing approaches, since there are persons who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and from them come those who act in the opposite way.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if it runs out after many days of putrid matter, then know that the sinus does not attach.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	But if the attachment of the sinus is prolonged and its matter is dried up: then let physicians add to it in their medicine so that they make it moist in its substance, and in its virtue dry: as the unguent of daphno, when added thereto an excess of addition out of myrrh.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the greatest last which is cured, is it that ye take the unguent of daphno, and dissolve it with rose-oil, and it runs over on the old sinuses equalling its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then bind the unguent to the sinus, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And this same action is similar when ye have not present to you the unguent of daphno, but ye have with you honey, when ye boil it up, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Take myrrh and aloe and olive oil; and let them all be crushed together, and put that powder on honey as it comes out of the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then spread a sheet over the wound, and tie it tightly around the sinus; and spread the powder on the wound, and put it on the sheet, and tie it tightly.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when the long arhatolgia is administered to it, and the roots of the star lily, and there is a lily; and flour from grass, and daisy.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple, or crushed, spread it out, and the powder itself: and put that honey which you have made, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the sinus does not heal with this treatment, then you shall know that there is corruption in its depths: or it has already made an impression on the bones, or on the other hard members, or on the ligaments: then treat the sinus with fistular cure, according to what has been stated.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Of the cure of paronychia and of the grinding of the nail, and of the incision of the finger added, and of the section.
Caput XCI.	Chapter XCI.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Paronychia is an abscess that arises under the nail of the thumb or any other finger, and perhaps it arises in the other fingers too.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When it is prolonged and neglected, and left without treatment, and becomes an abscess with a hot poultice: or itrotts and discharges pus, until it corrodes the nail root: and perhaps it corrupts all of it, and perhaps the corruption reaches the mouth, until it gives off a foul odor: and makes the end of the finger swollen, and its color is black.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you then treat the sinus with what we have said in the division, and your treatment does not bring about a cure: then you must cut off all the excess that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after it.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For the cautery is very hot.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	But if the mouth is sound, and the nail also is sound, and the additions of the nail are already pressing inwards the flesh towards its interior, and they begin to sting it, and hurt it: then you must place a very fine radium under the angle of the nail that hurts the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut into the flesh easily, and put on top of it what remains of the flesh from burning medicines, from corrosions, until all of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then that care with ointment, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If however the corruption has already sunk deep into the palate, then one should break open that palate and take it out: for it is never healed while the corrupted palate remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see corrosion and corruption entering into the finger, then cut it at one of its joints, according to the above-mentioned reminder.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for that wound, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If however there is an injury from scraping or striking: and there is sharp pain, then one should let the blood of that person first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp spatula, cutting across from above to the wound.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard it, so that the cut does not go down into the flesh below the nail, for you will cause to happen through it a very painful pain in the sick one, and it will be a cause of the birth of flesh added in place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for that place with what sits and has pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger however that is added which is born in some hands of men, perhaps is flesh all over: and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail in it: and the birth of some of their joints, or is born in some of their joints.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	So this which is born in some joints of the finger does not move: and this which is born at the joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore that flesh from which it is easy to cut, their section is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, so that you break open it at its root with a spatula of a flat edge.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the care of that which is born in the root of a joint, is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore abstain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In that finger however which is born at the last joint, then one should break open its first flesh all the way to the mouth.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then close the mouth with one of those sharp things that are convenient for closing it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then the cure of himself, until he is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	The consolidations that happen to the fingers together, often happens or from birth of man, that is, he is born with it, or from the consolidation of the wound, or from burning fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, it should be that you separate that consolidation, until the fingers regrow their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them a piece of linen, or rags soaked in rose water: so that they do not come together quickly, and separate them: or place between them a thin lead plate, until the site consolidates as needed.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And likewise, if the consolidation of some fingers with the palm, then dry that consolidation, according to which it is prepared and suitable for the member's form.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	De incisione:
Caput XCII.	Chapter LII on the head:
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Veins that are swollen, large, and filled with melancholic superfluities which occur in many parts of the body: and most of them are found in the legs, especially in the thighs of those who move about a lot, work hard, or carry heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, it should be that you administer the body with a strong dose of black choleric, sometimes through vigorous perspiration.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then take blood from the patient in a sitting position.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of those veins with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One is, so that they sit and black blood is drawn from them.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is, so that the vein is ligated, and all of it is extracted.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The sectioning of this is according to this method:
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Wrap the leg first with hot water, until the thick, putrid blood is resolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tighten the leg of the patient from the upper part of the hip to the lower part of the knee with thread, using the rope.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry the vein at one place, or two, or three wide sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then draw blood from the lower part of the leg to the upper, and from the upper should it be drawn by the phlebotomist first while the patient is still standing.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut off the nail down to the bottom: until it has run out of blood as much as you see is sufficient, and as much as strength endures.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bandage it up: and tell him to refrain from foods that cause black chill: and again drainage and bloodletting when the veins are filled, and this hurts the sick person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	But his elevation is according to this mode.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the wound, if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then introduce himself into a bath: or wet himself in his own leg with warm water, until he turns red, and the veins swell: or exercise himself strongly, if there is no bath present, until he warms the limb.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin in the direct section of the vein along its length: or at the end of it by the knee, or in the lower part of it by the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with a hook, and scrape the vein from all parts, until you can feel it: and it is at the appearance of it that you see it turn red from white by its decline.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When then you remove it from the skin, you see it white as a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce under it Radium, until it comes out and exits the skin: suspend it with a blind hook, gentle.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry another section next to that section by three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein, until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then apply Radium to it as you did, and suspend it with another hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry another section, or more sections, if you can endure it.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then apply Radium, and cut her last section at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then take it out to the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this, until you take it out from the upper section: or longer sections, until you have taken it all out: then cut her.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if he does not obey you in having it extracted and washed, then put a strong thread twice around it and tie it up and extract it: or insert under it radium: and withdraw your hand from all sides until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be careful so that it does not injure itself.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it injures itself, it will be difficult for you to wash it well, and it will get into the illness from it.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	So when you have extracted it all: then put on the wound wool dipped in wine and oil with a scent or oil: and take care of the wound, until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	That if the vine is contracted, it has a curvature where there is an innovation to its parts, and it is not like what we said according to the straightness: then you must find on it for all the parts of its curvature, and the places of its innovation.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then hang it up with a hook until you have washed it all: and be careful by your section on it so that you do not injure yourself or hurt yourself, for it will be difficult over you to wash it well or to extract it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Preserve therefore your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The Shape of the wound when the vine heals.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The shape of the hook.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not a curvature like the rest of the vine, and there is no acute extremity, so as not to injure a hand: and it has gross flexibility, soft: for if it were subtle, it would hurt a hand with its subtlety: but it has superfluous grossness, as we have said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	Of the extraction of the vein of the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter LIII.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is born in the legs in warm lands, such as that of the horse and of the Arabs, and in dry, hot lands, scant of grass, that is to say, in those where no草 grows, nor trees.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is born in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And this generation is indeed from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, as they occur within the bodies of snakes and worms of the ascaroidea, and worms that are generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this venereal disease is a severe inflammation of the thigh.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place becomes swollen and painful.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to come out of the place of its swelling, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When then it appears from this extremities, then you shall bind the same with a screw of lead, whose weight is a drachm of brass, to two drachms and mark it: and then take off the lead that is hung on the thigh.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever then it goes out from this anything to the outside, bind the same in lead and mark the same.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	That if it is prolonged for a long time, then he will cut off a part of it, and bind the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And you shall not cut it off its root before it goes out all.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you shall cut it off, then it will contract, and enter into flesh: and it makes happen a blister, and putrefaction in the place, and a bad wound.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it shall be that it is suavly handled, and taken out gradually, until it goes out from its last end, and remains nothing of it in the body: and from this very vein go out in some men, who is in length of his five palms and ten fingers.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And then he came to me, for he went out by a penis that was twenty palms long.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if you shall be cut on you in the hour of your medication: then you shall introduce a rod into its opening, and pierce it through a long way with the body, until all that is in it is discharged out of the same matter: and you shall administer putrefaction of the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care of him in the cure of the blister.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein has branches in many places, especially when it appears in the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself; and many openings happen to it, and a branch comes out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Take care therefore of itself, as we have said in the division, and with what precedes.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	[On] Section on worms that are born under the skin, and it is called "Illness of the cattle.
Caput XCIIII.	Head [108].
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This sickness is called in some country among us "Illness of the cattle": because it often happens to the cattle and is a pale flesh, which is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it leaves the whole body, going up and down: and is perceived by the sense in walking with its limb from one member to another, until it breaks off where it has broken off in the skin, and goes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the decay of some humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As worms and snakes happen, that is, earthworms, and roundworms in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And are afraid of its evil.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it leaves the body and rises to the head and comes to a place: then perhaps it opens in it, and goes out, and destroys the eye: and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	But when you are to treat it, and to remove it, then it is not done by the sense of touch or sight.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	It must be, that you should tie what is above it, and what is under it with a strong cord.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry off on top of it, and remove it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it has sunk into the flesh, and not hurt itself: then put over the place a cauldron with fire, until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than this, which is feared, is its decay, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see it having already come to the head near the eye, then tie under it a good tight cord.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry upon the flesh, and pull it out.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is fitting that the sick one should use his own purification of his body with medicines that dissolve the bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	[De] Section [i.e., cutting] on disease [the part] of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter LXXV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This disease is called in our tongue Nakir, and it is a pain that occurs in some part; then it changes from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And indeed I have already seen him, according as I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in some wounds.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she laid her arm on me; and I saw an inflammation of the lung in the broncia [i.e., windpipe].
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I had left for an hour, I saw one inflammation running with fire as it ran down from her shoulder; and it went up to her arm more rapidly than she could run: so that it was like silver in motion when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	So the pain then disappeared from that part, and remained fixed in her shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then after I had left for an hour, it ran into the rest of the body until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that it was pulsing all over his body; for I saw it.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was therefore astonished at the speed of its change from one member to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed I had not seen this disease with my eyes before it ran in this way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I saw many who found the disease to change from one member to another: and I did not see it with my eyes as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that this was because she is from those who are from dried-up wounds of the skin; therefore, it follows that this changeability of motion seems to be due to wind.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that those who are not affected by this should not appear in this way in those who are languid and have moist bodies; hidden wounds.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When then you shall take the cure of his eye, and he shall feel that pain: if it appear to thee in his eye, as we said, then thou shalt bind it above him, and under him likewise quickly: and dry it above him, till he go out that windiness: and causticate the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see the eye with your eyes: then cure that eye with the removal of the body, and with it the windiness that it expels, and with carminative pills made from foul-smelling plants, and with pills made from serax and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	[On the Extraction of Arrowheads].
Caput XCVI.	CHAPTER LXXVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows differ according to their species, and according to the places in which they are lodged in the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Of these there is a variety, for some have large points, and some small; and some are conched, and some are flattened.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And of these there is one which has three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And of these are tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And of these are arrows.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those however which lodge in the limbs, fall according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For the limbs are conched from those principal members, such as the brain, and the heart, and the liver, and the lung, and the kidneys, and the intestines, and the urinary bladder, and those like them.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When then it falls into one of these limbs, and you see the signs of death, which I will tell you about later, then you must extract the arrow from among them, for death follows it in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	But when those bad signs are not apparent to you, and the arrow is not hidden deep within the limb, then draw it out, and mend the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when the signs occur in the brain when an arrow falls into it, and pierces the bone, and comes out above the brain, there occur from it: for there is a violent jaundice, and stuttering, and giddiness, and redness in the eyes, and swelling, and cramp in the tongue, and convulsions, and confusion of thought, and forgetfulness.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will flow from the nostrils, or from the ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and the ox is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And moisture that is like white pus may flow from the wound's site.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it shall issue therefrom a substance similar to meat soupy in consistency.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If these signs appear to you, then refrain from cure, and draw out the arrow if it has not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the arrow when it falls into the heart are these: that is near the left nipple: and it feels as if it were fixed in a hard thing, not in a soft thing.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow has a movement similar to that of a pulse: and black blood flows from the neck.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And follows this chill in the extremities, and cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	So you see that death has come without a doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	The sign of the arrow when it wounds the lung is the flow of foamy blood from the neck; and the veins that follow the spine are pale, and their color changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out great, deep breaths; and seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into a rib cage which is in the breast: then it is near the back ribs: and it causes a great longing with a throbbing pain, with a sigh: and all the limbs of the arms move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps it flows out from the neck with some uneaten food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach and becomes stuck there: it flows out from the neck some stool, or dung, or a torn intestine which has already been ruptured.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is therefore no hope of curing it, nor of drawing out the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow falls into the bladder and flows out urine: and proceeds from it something to the outside, and the pain is stronger on the sick person: then you know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remains of the limb, such as the face, neck, throat, spatula, aid, dorsal spondylarthroses, furcula, hip, thigh, and shin bones, and similar bones from the limb are preserved according to various dispositions: when the arrow does not hit an artery or nerve; and it is not a penetrating arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I will tell you that I saw such arrows exist, as you indicate by that one about your curing.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because a certain man had an arrow hit his eye's tear duct, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So I removed it from him on the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I drew out another arrow from the Jew, which had hit him in the fat of his eye under his lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I could not get it out except for its far end, which held to its own wood; and it was a big arrow of Turkish arrows, with a soft iron point, where there are no flanges.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	So the Jew was healed, and no harm came to his eye with that accident.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I drew out another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabic arrow, and that one has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I followed it with two guides between the two; and it was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	So subtle was I with it, that I drew it out: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I drew out another arrow from the belly of a man who had fallen into his belly: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After that had passed over him thirty days, and there was no change in his disposition from what I had seen before the arrow; so I followed the arrow up, and I managed it, and drew it out: and he was healed, and no harm came to him with that accident.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	I saw a man who had an arrow shoot through his back, and there was a bone that had become firm over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	Afterwards, then, having elapsed seven years, the arrow was drawn out from the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman who had an arrow shoot through her belly, and there was a bone that had become firm over it, and the arrow remained within her: and there was no change in any of her natural dispositions, and she did not find any harm in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man, who had an arrow shoot through his face: and there was a bone that had become firm, and remained, not finding much pain therein: and there were many others like this.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I took the arrow out of the king's sons from the middle of his nose, and it had already begun to decline towards the right side a little: and the whole arrow was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	So I was called to treat him after the arrow was shot out until three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the arrow's shaft very tight.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	So I examined it carefully, and could not feel it: but he himself felt a prick and pain under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that was where the prick came from.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	So I applied plaster to the spot with the adhesive and digestive power, confiding to him that it would dry up the place, and let me know the sign of the arrow, so that I might break over it: but nothing happened in that place indicating that the arrow had followed its course.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	So I applied the plaster to him for several days: and nothing happened, and the bone had become firm while: he remained weak with respect to taking it out of space for a certain day, so that he felt an arrow shoot through his nose on a certain day.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me about that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	So I put acute medicine on that bone for several days, until it healed open: and when I tried to move him, I felt the arrow's slight prick sticking to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added, through the acute medicine, to the opening of the wound until we could see the end of the arrow; and passed about four months with it.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then, after the swelling had increased, and it seemed possible to me to introduce my fingers into it and move them, and it did not comply with exit; then I did not cease to be delicate, and devise means for it with engineering devices, until one day I managed to do it with a kind of crooked hooks, according to which the shape of them came at the end of the chapter, so I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the fracture.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the doctors are saying that the cartilage of the nose has not been restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	So I restored it, and the fracture was consolidated, and the health returned to its complete health: nor did he suffer from anything at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will tell you the quality of the extraction of certain arrows: that you put that rule and meaning on it which I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts of this art and their distinctions are not understood by narration: nor does it understand that book, and the craftsman compares little to much: and when something is absent, he finds a new operation, and a new instrument for the descent of external things of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I will say then, that arrows do not come out of the body in which they are fixed, except by two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place into which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by the reverse of another part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out from where it entered, or is an arrow proceeding in a fleshy place: and is attracted, and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	That if it does not comply with exit within the hour in which it falls: then you must leave it for a few days, until it putrifies the flesh which is around it: and its attraction will be relieved, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And also if it is lodged in a bone, and does not comply with you to exit: then leave it for a few days: and again bring it out with attraction and movement every day, until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If he does not obey you until after a few days, then it is necessary that you cut off the whole skull with a thin saw, until the sutures are increased.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract him and remove him.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the skull bone and has already entered one of the ventilations of the brain, and it appears that there is something of the accidents which I mentioned: then refrain from attracting the arrow, and let go of it until it is equal to being after a few days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the top, then death does not prolong itself for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	But if the arrow has not penetrated far and remains only in the bone without reaching the top, and the sick person remains so for a few days and nothing of those accidents happens to him: then use your cunning in attracting the arrow and removing it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is fixed firmly, and does not obey you in the attraction: then apply a thin saw around the arrow, as I told you: then take care of the place, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow is already hidden and concealed in the body, and hidden from sense: then seek it out with effort.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then attract it with some instruments that are suitable for attracting it.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you cannot reach it because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the arrow in the depth, and there is no bone or nerve or blood there: then find it out, until the vein increases, and it becomes possible to remove the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	That if they are ears which hold it fast from all parts, with any device that you can: and use your cunning if it cannot be freed by the movement of the flesh in the breaking of the ears, and their twisting, until it is satisfied.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you, when you administer the extraction of the arrow, in whichever part it is, then use the twisting of your hands with tweezers to all parts, until you make it satisfied: and the last subtility, so that the arrow does not break, and it becomes difficult for you to attract it, and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot bind it in a single hour, then release it after some days, until what is around it putsrefies.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then apply the poultice again: for indeed bandages do harm if there is a contrary flux of blood, then administer what we said in its own chapter: and guard your virtue from the incision of the vein, or nerve, or chord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer ointment in every way that is possible to you of the Sarmentum: and let it be with facility, and tranquility, or slowness, and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that, when you draw the Arrow, you make it so that the infirm person is according to the figure, according to what was in the case of the Arrow in itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more a matter of judgment.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	But if this is not possible for you, then administer what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	But the Arrow which comes from the opposite part, or which has already gone out a little towards the outside: or which makes the extreme end of the Arrow to protrude by sensation from the upper part of the skin near it, and see that it is emerging: so cut it off above, and let the section be according to the quantity which enters into it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then attract it: for indeed it is easy to come out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.
