But if it is held in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness, until the Arrow presses into the bone, and expands itself: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: release it for some days: and then apply it again, until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the wood of the Arrow is in it, then push it with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if it has fallen, and you are to administer a push: then introduce the tool that is sharp, so that its sharpness enters into the tail of the Arrow: and then push it with that.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	But if the Arrow is closed, then push it with the instrument entering into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	And the arrow is healed by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	For if the arrow is poisoned, then you should cut away all the meat in which there is poison, and if it is possible for you to get that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of him with that which suits him concerning that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	That if the arrow is falling in the breast, or in the belly, or in the vesicle, or in the loin: and it is close to you that you touch with your hand, and it is possible for you to cut over it: then cut, and carefully from the incision of the flesh, or of the nerve, and pull it out.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then bend the arm, if you see it, and take care of that, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form Of Forcings, with which Arrows are pulled out.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Behold that they are similar to the tips of arrows, made like iron: when they grasp it over the Arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And they are of many kinds, great and small, and medium, according to the quantity of the size of the Arrow, and the smallness of the wound, and the constriction of it.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	Form of the Impeller Here is a description of the form of the impeller: It has four pieces of metal, like blades, joined to each other; and the blade that is nearest to the arrow is broader at one end and narrows towards the other.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the Impeller is dull.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is like the ends of a radii, that the entrance into the arrow may be facilitated, and driven in with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This end of the impeller is conved like a feather of an arrow: that the entrance into the Arrow may be facilitated, and its driving with it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Concerning the Phlebotomy of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Head LXXVII.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	There are thirty veins for phlebotomy, of which the custom is established in the body.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of which there are six in the head: two pulsating veins, which are behind the ears, called the two Herbs; and two arteries, which appear in two times: and two veins, which are in the two eyelids of the two eyes, called the Aspiring ones; and a vein that is prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein that is in the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two guide-strings, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two strings, which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two strings, which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These are the strings called Al-Ja'far.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two strings that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	But the veins that are phlebotomized in the arms, there are five strings in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the cephalic vein, and it comes from the lateral side of the skull; it is called the common vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And the median vein, which is composed of a basal branch and a cephalic branch; it is called the common vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the basilic vein, and it is placed on the internal lateral side: it is also called the titillary vein.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it is called the common vein of the leg.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the tendon of the biceps, and it is placed on the back of the forearm; and this is the one that is phlebotomized, and it is the one that appears above the thumb by the apparent compression.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the salvatory vein; and it is a vein between the round and little fingers, and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	In the thigh and in the foot there are three strings.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is that which is below the thumb by the lateral side, from the wrist to the elbow.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the saphenous vein; its position is at the heel from the internal lateral side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the plantaris vein; its position is also at the heel, from the lateral side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	In the other leg, there are three similar strings.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Regarding the phlebotomy of two veins behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The phlebotomy of two veins behind the ears is a treatment for old hematomas, hemiplegias, syphilis, and bad ulcers of the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the phlebotomy should be as follows:
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And so he shaves the head of the patient and rubs his scalp with a rough cloth in the space between two eyebrows.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the sick man strings his neck with a thong until two eyebrows appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And these are the places behind the ears, in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Ask then your finger, and where you feel the pulse of his ears under your finger, there mark with a caustice.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take a scalp-candle, and that one is called an "incision".
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce him under the eyebrow until he reaches the nose.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then wash your hand with the eyebrow and the skin towards the top, and cut the eyebrow with a cut of incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And the length of the incision is the amount of two fingers spread out, or about that: and make come out of the blood as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tie it with powder, and let it go, until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now preceded in the beginning of the book of incision of ears, and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	The phlebotomy of two arteries in the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	But two arteries which are in the two temples of phlebotomy, is to an ancient hemorroid: and salt the nape, and press steadily: and run the course of the flowing acutes to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of phlebotomy for you I will tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	Then the sick man strings his neck much, until two eyebrows appear by a manifest appearance: and she shows you the pulse of his ears under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	For then the signs with a caustice.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then wash the skin above the eyebrow with your index finger, and introduce a scalpel behind, and wash the eyebrow above.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it, as you did in the two eyebrows, and let the blood run according to the amount of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then حل حلقة الجروح، ووضع يدك فوقها لمدة ساعة واحدة.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	بعد ذلك ضع الغرز فوقها وأضف بعض الجبائر، وشد الحبل بقوة حوله: ثم أرخِه حتى يشفى.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	وبعد أن يتذكر الرجل ما حدث له، وجرحه، وكيف قام باستخراجه في البداية من الكتاب.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	(يتحدث عن فصاحة دم الجبهة بعد فصاحة الدم على الرأس)
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	إن إجراء فصاحة دم الجبهة بعد فصاحة الدم على الرأس هو في الحقيقة لعلاج أمراض الوجه القديمة، وللصداع النصفي، والارتباك، والأورام الدموية. كما يمكن أن يساعد في علاج القرح البشعة.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	وإن نوع فصاحة الدم التي سألتك عنها هي:
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	(يتضمن) حلقة ضيقة حول رقبة المريض حتى يظهر الدم.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	خذ الأداة التي تسمى (فاسوريا).
Cuius haec est forma.	(فهي ذات شكل) مثلث.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	ضع نقطة بارزة في رأس الفاسوريا فوق الجرح، واطردها على الدم باستخدام مشط أو أداة أخرى بطريقة ما؛ ثم أطلق الدم ليتدفق حسب الكمية التي تريدينها.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	ثم حل ثقب الجرح، وشد الحلقة حتى يشفى.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	وأحياناً عندما يفتح مع الفصاحة العريضة.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	ومع ذلك، لا ينبغي أن يكون فصاحة حادة جداً، مثل بقية الفصاحات، لذلك يجب أن تكون عريضة بعض الشيء.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	وإذا كان الفصاحة بعيدة عن الفتحة، فهذا أفضل، لأن الفتحة قريبة منه، وربما ينكسر الفصاحة عندما يكون رفيقاً.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	(يتحدث عن فصاحة  في الجفنين)
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	لكن الوعد بخصوص فصاحة الجفينين في عينين هو لعلاج التهاب شديد في العينين، وربما يكون هناك بعض الدم، أو صداع في العين، وأمراض الوجه.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And what is the quality of phlebotomy, so that it may bind the neck of the sick with a bandage.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then phlebotomize them: and you are standing over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the phlebotomy be made according to a traverse at a little distance along the length, with a little phlebotomist, slightly on the side, for there is no flesh in the place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the phlebotomist is sharp at the end, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let the blood run out as much as you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place over them a cloth, and tie them up for the night, and unbind them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of the phlebotomy of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	But the veins of the nose are useful for a acute fever, and a rushing pulse, and ailments of the face, such as a headache, and a ruddy color that comes into the face: especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And what is the quality of phlebotomy, so that it may bind the neck of the sick.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take his nose in your left hand, and take a little phlebotomist, long; and fasten it in the middle of his nose, between what separates the nose.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the vein does not appear to sense there, and because the blood begins to flow at once.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it should be, so that your hand with the phlebotomist is slightly less: and let the blood run out according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it for the night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it is quickly restored.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Of the phlebotomy of the guide.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	But two phlebotomies of the guide are useful for constriction of a sore throat, and the beginning of leprosy, and melancholy ailments, and an impetigo and bad ulcers, and corrosive sores, that is, herpes zoster.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And what is the quality of phlebotomy, so that it may bind the sick under each on his neck with a bandage: and let the craftsman stand over his head, and let the sick person sit on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then cut a vein about an inch in length with a wide blade.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then remove the amount of blood that is appropriate for the temperature, or according to what you see as necessary for that matter.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do likewise with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then loosen the ligaments and pinch two veins together tightly: so that the patient does not faint.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let it rest until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound heals well.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	This is Albucasis' discussion of vein extraction.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	But the extraction of veins, according to Albucasis' method, is dangerous: because it tends towards the drinking of alcohol, and corruption of the gingiva; and sores that are bad, as well as cracks of the lips, and sores that are bad also, even those that are in the nose, and around its circumference.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of vein extraction is that it keeps the sick person from sitting before you: and tighten his neck with a noose.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn the patient's lip and look at two veins: the one is on the right side of the lip, and the second is on the left: and the indication of both is by the color of amber.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because there are small veins around them, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Then cut each one of them as it falls.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if you have any hesitation about yourself, and you don't know which is which: then proceed to the incision of the larger veins, and make them more manifest.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do likewise with the two veins that are on the upper lip: and there is much, indeed, of custom with him: and cut two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	This is Albucasis' discussion of vein extraction under the tongue after the phlebotomy of the head.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	But the two veins that are under the tongue have a dangerous phlebotomy: because the phlebotomy of the head is for the pre-focations that are in the throat, and the sickness of the mouth, and the sickness of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And what is the quality of phlebotomy, so that the sick person sits between your hands before the sun: and anoint his tongue, and look under his tongue on one side, and on the other side: and the color of both decline to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	So phlebotomy both: and guard, so that you do not put your hand on them when you are phlebotoming them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under them are the arteries, and perhaps it happens that the flow of blood comes out from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of three veins on the bed.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The veins, of which there are three that are phlebotomized in the bed, are in which the custom of phlebotomy runs in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And phlebotomy is done from them according to two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or piercing with the phlebotome on one side: or anointing to the subtility of the decline: or drying with the phlebotomizer and it is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	So Alnesil is, which is suitable for the section.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them are species wide, and subtle according to the width of the veins and the form of the phlebotomizer with a blade, as you see it.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening closed veins, full, coming from, appearing, thick, and those that contain gross, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomist is of lesser width, and more subtle in the extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for the phlebotomy of subtile veins, which contain citriny blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Of the phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	But the Basilica, which is a single vein of the three veins that are phlebotomized, is the iuuamentum.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the ailments that are under the throat and neck, from this it follows that it goes into the chest and belly: and it is suitable for the phlebotomist to phlebotomize her, so that he does not fear, and sit on the edge of [the] fear from her, since under her is the artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If he should mistake and add a needle to the puncturing of the vein, he would cut the artery and cause a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore, he should not add a needle when puncturing with the phlebotome: let him stand apart with Anesiacum.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If the Basilica does not appear with a clear manifestation, then you should remove it and replace it with another one, or seek out one of its branches: or you can place the phlebotome at the site of the bursa of the elbow.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For this is manifest, and dry it with Anesiacum phlebotome, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	But if you want to make a phlebotomy on the same arm, then you should do it before the elbow joint, so that you can find the place of pulsation.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the spot with caustic powder, then wrap the arm, and dry up the vein with a needle, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And let it not fall by chance into the space of the artery's place.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see that it is swollen at the place where you have marked with caustic powder, then this swelling is the swelling of the artery: so remove it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see blood rise at the site of phlebotomy, like a boy's urine, and it is pale blood, then know that it comes from the artery's blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	So then put your hand on the spot for a long time, and then take away your hand.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If then blood is separated (for it is often separated) let the arm be held still, and let go of that part: and guard against its movement: and let it rest on fear for it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move that part for a few days, until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if the blood does not separate and hurts you: and there is no medicine present for your moment, then cut the artery if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities are bruised, and blood is separated.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	And take hold of the fascicle of skin and find it out; and take hold of a half, and bind it tightly over the place of the wound that is descending with the ligament and down to another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then take care of himself with what remains of the reminder from the place of the flow of blood that has been cut off: and the cutting off of his blood is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the small wound place, and the possibility of the ligament out of the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Of the phlebotomy of the skin of the pig.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	But the venose of the pig is a phlebotomy that draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower body: because it is composed of the branch of Basilica and the branch of Cephalica, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it fits the phlebotome so that he is afraid of his phlebotomy, because there is a nerve under it.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	But if he adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy and finds the nerve, it happens in her stupor, and difficult is its cure, and perhaps does not cure thoroughly.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears many times to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in some people and is subtle, and does not show itself: then you must put your phlebotomy so that he finds the phlebotomist, and a section with Alnesil, and far from the nerves with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	That if the pig is between two nerves, then find a pig in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Of the pig of the head.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	But the phlebotomy of the pig of the head is a phlebotomy because it draws blood from the head, and brings to the ailments of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it must be in this pig proper, if you want, so that you phlebotomy it piercing with the phlebotomist oileum, or with the phlebotomist Myrtle: for it is healthier of all the pigs, because there is no artery under it, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	Indeed, it is fitting that you should go to the phlebotomist's shop, for he will only tie a knot on your head, and you should inquire about a gentler place: and it does not hurt him if it is not discovered with a first punch, so that it may be renewed several times with phlebotomy.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Indeed, perhaps you should cauterize certain people when they are not phlebotomized in the first punch, but it does not hurt him that cauterization in some way.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the Usefulness of Phlebotomy and the Observation of Cauterization in It.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The Qualities and Complications of Phlebotomy and What You Should Consider in Their Correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First, therefore, of these things you need to know, that phlebotomy is administered not unless for the preservation of health, and perseverance in it, and caution against the advent of sicknesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And so phlebotomy is done in one of three positions which are in a bed, namely: the cephalica, and the fusca, and the basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And so phlebotomy is done at the beginning of spring on a fast, and in summer: and in autumn, and winter after feasting, when there are indications of fullness.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And so phlebotomy should be done on the first or third day after having passed three hours from a meal.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	But phlebotomy that is administered in sicknesses has not a determined time: but when it provokes conveniently and necessity to it, in the night, or in the day, and at all times, and at all times.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not necessary that boys should be phlebotomized until they are fourteen years old.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should a pregnant woman be phlebotomized before the fourth month and after the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should seniors who have already passed sixty years be phlebotomized.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	But when anyone is to be phlebotomized however it may be: it is necessary that he should purge his bowels before phlebotomy with a soft laxative, if there is much waste matter retained in them: so that the blood shall not attract the skin of the limbs from the bowels by its putridity.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Do not let the patient bleed too much, that is, do not cause nausea; and do not let him sweat from drunkenness until he has removed it from himself.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Do not let the sick person have a water-based fever.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let phlebotomy be repeated after diarrhea, vomiting, flux of blood, increase in copulation, toil, exercise, vigils, fasting, and any other thing that dissolves virtue from the physical body or animal substance.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider with care before doing this, if the blood is thick with food and drink and medicine: if it can be done to him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let him bathe in lukewarm water, if he does not object to it for anything: or let him exercise himself in some kind of exercise, that his blood may be softened.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And put phlebotomy to him in his chest, about the third day as we have said: and be careful that his chest be empty of all animal evil that day: such as anger, fear, and worry: and all bodily evils, such as toil, punishment, overindulgence, and such like.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him make his own things present with him when he is in his own country, so that he may have the use of what is customary to humans from aromatic substances, and smells, and delights, and similar things by quantity of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the phlebotomist sit on a table, which shall be higher than the phlebotomy table: then shall he take his arm out, and rub it with his own hand twice, or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then let him tie a ligature with the cord, and twist it round two turns.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the constriction be tight, because a constriction is not equal when it is too much or by excess of constriction, then it prevents the flow of blood: or in relaxation, then also it prevents the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the constriction, let the phlebotomist rub his hands together back to front, until the blood rises and feels good to the touch.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist removes the blood with little oil, of his own making.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he places his index finger of his left hand on the venation at the place where he plans to make a phlebotomy, little by little: so that the blood does not flow away, and the vessel is not injured by the pricking.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For from the venations there flows blood as does a string when phlebotomy is performed: and from them there comes blood of good flow: and when you place the phlebotome on it, it is pressed by the phlebotome, and the phlebotomist is deceived, and does not open the vein: and if he opens it, it is tight; therefore, so that the phlebotomist may be firm and alert in all these things,
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	then let him place the phlebotome.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If then one vein opens from one drop of blood, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat the same drops a few times under that place or above it with some haste: if not, then find another place.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	That if it is not pricked, or if it grows weak, then let him leave it for a day or two: and do not tighten the ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps indeed does attract the cold apostema.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And let no bath be made.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then let him repeat the phlebotomy if he likes it.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	That if the opening is small, or blood flows slowly: and let him time so that not a drop of blood goes out of the amount that you wish: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same place according to the straightness, and add to the procedure a little bit.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with some haste, before that place is pricked: for indeed that place is pricked in many people during the procedure if it is small.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If then you see the person already pricked, then do not repeat the phlebotomy on that place at all: for indeed it is no excuse with you to make a mistake.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place on the venation some of the soft oil: for it will ease the course of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than oil itself, and than the rest of the oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And likewise administer the oil of the earth in all your phlebotomies, wherever you do phlebotomy with the prohibition of the course of blood; and make that which is called Tyrocum (Toryon) and sagzene (sagxe), when it is put from one of them on the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For the blood is thinned and resolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	That if it should happen in the place of phlebotomy a great aposteme, for many times it happens, especially to him who is not phlebotomized except at that time, or is a small opening of the vein, then immediately put over the place a sponge infused with water and salt, heated slightly: and tie it one hour: for it is resolved.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you should do that which is called a tyrocum  (Toryon) after the exit of blood from the vein itself with its complement, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	That if it remains in the place after a certain time of blackening, or of verdigris, it does not hurt that which is called a tyrocum   (Toryon); and if it is a vein, put over it some oil, or dissolved myrrh: or some juice of mint, that is, of calamus or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many times happen apostemes and eminences at phlebotomy in the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Then put your hand over it, then if it is soft to touch under your pressure on it, then that eminence is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Care therefore, that you put over it some of that which we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood flows from that vein.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a patch with it where there is a stenosis, so that the place may be hardened.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the hand itself with the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you should give to every man out of his own blood according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears from the bright color on top of the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	If the blood is black, then let him leave it until it turns red: and if he sees it is thick, then let him leave it until it thins out: and if he sees it is sharp, then let him wait until its sharpness goes away.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And he who is full, strong, and resistant to the extraction of blood, let him draw it once, so that the phlebotomy of the vein may be increased, and let the phlebotomist stand on his left side: and in regard to him who is weak, let him stand on the opposite side.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And let him draw the blood from the veins, and let there be a tight opening; and it is better that what is administered in the phlebotomy of the vein should be a transverse section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is healthier and safer than the incising of the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy and healthier than phlebotomy by way of width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And he who is accustomed to fainting during phlebotomy, let him eat a little bit of bread soaked in grape juice before phlebotomy with moderate heating: or secani-bin, if he is warm: and let there be extracted from his blood in three veins, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if he has a cold complexions, then let him take before phlebotomy bread soaked in honey syrup, or in honey syrup seasoned with spices, or in syrup seasoned with an aromatic smell.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	That if it should happen that a syncopation occurs during phlebotomy, and there is a cause of his blood's exit: then let him drink in a bowl water of flesh, and syrup of the subtle aromatic: and let him use the aromatic with the algaria, and let him spread his chest while doing so: and let him use the rest which we have said in the distribution in the chapter on syncopes from the extraction.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	But he who wants to recover his arm, and to let his blood flow a second time: it is necessary for him who has had phlebotomy because of excessive extraction, and whose power is weak, that he should let his blood flow little by little according to the strength in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to set his broken arm in place, and to stop the flow of blood by means of second application, and the body is strong; then he should do so after seven hours, or nine from the time of the first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his body to the opposite part to which he leans: it is necessary that he should do this on the second day or the third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body there is much blood already heated and sharpened, and which causes fever: it is necessary that he should be taken out of it a certain quantity of blood, and that so much blood be drawn from him as will increase the opening until syncope occurs; after you have preserved all the conditions of phlebotomy; and in order that you may put your hand upon his pulse at the place where the blood flows, so that death by syncope does not occur.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For many times it happens that the phlebotomist does not know and falls through carelessness.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not when you wish to set the arm in place, and to stop the flow of blood by means of a second application, that the orifice of the vein is already closed, and the exit of blood becomes difficult, so that it presses upon him with vehemence, and turns quickly inward.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is a bad wound, deeply let go, until he is phlebotomized for the second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or move it with keenness of phlebotomy that which is coagulated from blood at the orifice of the vein, and put upon him a certain amount of dissolved salt in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place upon him some of the tar-water or the sagden, and place the body with gentle compression until blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If, however, the vein is already blistered, then let go of it, and do not press it, until it returns to its normal state.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	That if necessity compels to stop the flow of blood by means of a second application, and there is no excuse, then either phlebotomize him above that place, or in another arm into another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But the vein of the arm is opened at the place of the fustuce and the basilica, when they are not found and are hidden, because it is made of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of its opening, that the sick person puts his hand in hot water, until it turns red, and the new one appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it is bound over it with a little tightening of the ligament.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then the bloodletting is done according to the direction of the veins, not according to their length, and the opening is wide, and your bloodletting is done over the bandage of the hand a little bit.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the blood flow is prevented, then take the hand again into hot water, and let the blood run into the water, until you have the need to stop it.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you were in the days of summer, then you are excused from the repetition of putting the hand into hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed the course of blood in hot water is long during the cold season.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the bloodletting of this vein is healthier for all veins, because it is not a pulsating vein, nor is there a nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	But bloodletting on the right hand of the patient confers health on the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of its opening is that you squeeze the hand with a little ligament, or your hand, after you have put it into hot water, until the new one bends, and is clearly felt to be sore.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then the bloodletting is done by crossing it.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it completely, it will not hurt that thing at all.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And keep your hand away from bloodletting.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For under it are the nerves of the fingers denuded of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then take the hand again to hot water, and let the blood run in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not repeat it in hot water, the blood will coagulate at the opening of the vein, and the flow will be prevented.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	So when you have extracted a certain quantity of blood from necessity, then put oil and salt on it so that it does not harden faster.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And in the same way, you should do with all broken limbs.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The instrument for phlebotomy from the left hand is this: since it is related to splenitis: and likewise do with its phlebotomy, as you did with the second one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The instrument for phlebotomy of the veins is for ailments that are in the lower part of the body, such as ailments of the uterus, and retention of menstruation, and ailments of the kidneys, and old sores of the hips and thighs, and similar ailments from illnesses.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of its phlebotomy is that it should put the sick foot into hot water: and make friction on it until the blood flows, and tie above the knot with a thong.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the place of the blood is at the heel, visible towards the thumb: and many branches come out of it towards the foot's face.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Phlebotomy should therefore do with a larger branch of it, or at its heel in the cluster: since it is better and healthier.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	That if you phlebotomize it in the foot's face, then be careful of the nerves that are under it on the foot's face.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy so as not to hit it: and let the phlebotomist be silent.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If blood flow is prohibited, then turn the foot of him into hot water: and let the blood run into it, until it flows.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	That if there is a mistake in the phlebotomizer in the first cut, then let it remain with phlebotomy towards the top for a while, since the place is healthy, and do not fear harm from it, when you are tapping the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And likewise with the other limb equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	But the location of the sciatic vein, as we have said, is at the heel from the side of the pine tree.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the treatment of varicose veins is to relieve pain due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that it should be done with warm water and dried off; and his leg should be bound up tightly from the hip to the heel for four hands, with a long thin strip: for indeed it does not appear except for this reason.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it does appear, then do the phlebotomy as well as you can according to your ability or turn; and it is better either to cut it off with a scalpel or to separate it by section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For the place of it is salutary, and itself is hidden to many people greatly.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If indeed you do not feel it at all: then phlebotomize some of its branches, and that which appears on the back of the foot, and towards the ear: and cut away from the nerves, and cause it to run with a quantity of blood as much as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then حلصه ہڈھ کے علاوۓ سے، اور اس میں ویسھ کھڑیں گے اور اس پر گھڑاں کرگے گے.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	جیدھ بھی آپ ہڈھ کو راحتی دے گے گے.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	وہ بات ہے کہ: "بھلوتومی کی سِتھ بھلوتومیا کا استعمال کرنا اور ان کی کیفیت".
Caput XCVIII.	(کاپيت ۈڵٹو)
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	ان سے بات میری جاتے ہیں: "بھلوتومیا کا استعمال گھڑیں اور نازک جانے سے ہوتا ہے".
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	وہ بات ہے کہ یہ دو तरह سے کرا جاتا ہے: "بھلوتومی کی ایک وڈیوں سے ہڈھ میں پڑکنے اور دوچھ رہنا".
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	یہ بات ہے کہ ہم دو بات کا بھلوتومی کی وڈیوں سے کرتے ہیں: "بھلوتومی میں نکالنا اور خون چھوکتا".
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this Ventosis which is without scarification, is according to two modes.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or indeed it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the Ventosis which are administered with scarification and extraction of blood are fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of these there is one, Ventosis of the noble, and it is last of the head: and Alkehel, and it is middle of the neck: and the Ventosis of the Al-Hadhdahim, and they are two folds of the neck from both sides simultaneously: and the Ventosis of the mind, and it is under the jaw in the lower mouth: and the Ventosis of the two spatulas: and the Ventosis of the Achhos on the end of the tail: and the Ventosis of the two flames, and they are middle of the two arms: and the Ventosis of the two knees: and the Ventosis of the two cheeks.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed Ventosis does not extract blood from you from small sparse veins in the flesh, and because of it the power does not fall from them, such as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	And it is not necessary that Ventosis be administered with fire or without fire in any illness that occurs from fullness, until the whole body is emptied.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	That if necessity compels to Ventosis from illness, or because of custom, we administer it at any hour at the beginning of the month, at its end, and at its middle, and at any other time.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	That is, because there is a person who, when blood multiplies within him, until it needs to be extracted by Ventosis, finds in his head a headache and dizziness.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And among them is one who finds fullness and redness of face in his head, neck, and throat.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And among them is one who finds itching in his face, forehead, darkness, and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And among them is one who scrapes the place of his Ventosis.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And among them is one whose laugh multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from these he has derived the taste of blood in his mouth: or let him lick his tongue, and let him spit out the blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from these his sleep increases.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from these his vision is increased while he sleeps; and he sees blood and redness, and those who are slain, and plaags, and things like them.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When then shall we see anything from these, and especially if it be in the third month: let us then put on the wind, after they have passed over two or three hours of the day.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	But the sign of Wind-panting is this: for it adds to the heaviness in the head, and that which is breathed forth goes into the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it is necessary that that be after the evacuation of all the body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this Wind is called Phleborrhagia cephalica.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it should not be used by one who has a cold complexione, or in whom there is a catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it infers great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And for this reason it should not be used by the elderly, and in whom there are diseases of the head due to cold.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But whoever uses this will fall into oblivion.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for this reason you should order the Wind-panter to put his hand down slightly towards the bottom, fearing the generation of oblivion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Wind-panter or Alchehol is called Phlebotomy of the Face, and phleboomy of the nose, and for this reason it adds smegma, constricts the windpipe, and makes fissures in the instrument of wind, and coughs, and fills up.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it should be driven out by Wind-panter slightly, for if it is put down lower, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Wind-panter is called Alchadhihim, it brings about pain to the accidents in the head, and to the eyes, and to the headaches, and to the perforations, and to the pain in the roots of the teeth; and it is the phlebotomy of the nose.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	It is fitting that you should refrain from cutting with the scissor [i.e., with a scalpel] before the wound has closed: so that it does not strike an artery and cause a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	But if there is a wound in the mouth, let him put alcohol in it and wash away the inflammation of the gums and similar ailments that are in the mouth; and let him stay where there is phlegm [i.e., a fluid] in the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	But if there is a wound with pus, let him go to the alchemist [i.e., an physician or surgeon], who makes it [the wound] well and cold.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	But if the wound is inside the body, let him use three scissors  [i.e., scalpels] of different sizes: the Basilica, the Fusca, and the Cephalica; for these draw blood from all the small veins that are in the flesh, and those small veins draw blood from the larger veins until the drawing reaches the three main veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is fitting that you should warn Ventosator not to cut too much: for the place is naked of flesh, and there are nerves and arteries underneath.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	But if a wound is ventsated on top of the anus, let it be applied to hemorrhoids and ulcers below.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is fitting that you should warn Ventosator not to make the wound too small, and not to use iron  [as a cutting implement]: for the place does not like strong suction, and perhaps the fine scalpels will break  [if applied too strongly]: and cut with a big cut.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	But the fine scalpels diminish little by little    [the wound]: for they draw blood from all the body, and cause old pains in the kidneys, and membranes, and vesicles: they provoke menses, and bring forth both urines, and wind; and stay where there is phlegm of the two saphenous veins and the alhorcobene.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, it weakens the body greatly, and causes fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	The joint of the hock is close to the joint of the two hind legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the hock is that you should place the foot in the first place without a grip, and wet with moderate suction: and do not prolong the position of the foot, but put it quickly and move it quickly so that the fluids come to the spot from all sides: and do not stop doing this and continue, until you see the spot already red and swollen, and it appears red with blood: then therefore cut, and repeat the suction slowly.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider in the arrangement of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For one who is of tender flesh and rare pores, it should be that you cut once only, not more: so that the spot does not ulcerate.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And order the hocker to amplify the incision and make it deep: and moderate the suction in ease, and quickly, and with a swaying motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	That if there is gloom in the blood, then you should cut the spot twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In a single blow the first incision opens the way for subtlety of blood, and makes it runny: and in the second blow of the perscrution of the subtle extraction of gross blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is very foul, then let the incision be made in a single blow: so that the last result is obtained.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And to the end, when we want to extract blood slowly, slightly, or at all, one incision is enough for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	That if we want multiple extractions of blood, let us make multiple incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we are measuring, that blood is thick: then it should be that the incision is deep: and the equal end of the incision is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is this that should be administered from oils in the arrangement of the hocks, and what does it caution the hocker?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that which the skin is thick, tough, dark, and whose pores are tight, it should be that the places of the hocks are anointed with open, gentle, and soft oils: if it is in the time of summer, such as is aleurites oil, or violet oil, or almond oil, or sesame seed oil.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	If it is in the season of winter, then then oil of Narcissus, or oil of Lily, or oil of Camomile, or Sarbatic oil: and to these similar ones.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	But if there is a gross superfluity, then cold oil: then amaranthine oil, or oil of Balsam, or white oil, or oil of Anise: and to these similar ones.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	But if it is a wind-ridden case of widespread diarrhea with tender meat, then one should be prevented from the oil, and these places should be cleaned with water rosated, or cold water, or water of sole, or water of cucurbits, or water of portulaca: and similar to them.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	But the one whose blood is of many humors should clean the wind-ridden cases with vinegar, or water of Myrtle, and Sumach: and similar to them.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	But if there is a gross superfluity, he should clean his wind-ridden cases with old wine, or with water of Samsou, or with a decoction of Anet, or of Camomile: and similar to them.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it should be prevented that the diarrhea occurs in a bath, or in a washing-place; but it should be administered after leaving the bath for an hour, or two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not appropriate for anyone to sleep after the diarrhea.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is needed so that the wind-ridden one is cured, or the phlebotomized one before the diarrhea?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after that, you should consider in the first place: then if it is a wind-ridden one, or a phlebotomized one, whether there is an acuteness and inflammation in his blood: then he should take something to cool him down, such as granatum muscat; also with vinegar and lettuce, and secaniabin, and juleb: and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And put away from him his spicy foods, and any meat that causes asecation, and cooked foods with berries: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	If his complexions are cold, he should take syrup made from honey, or from almond milk, or alsecania, made from seed; and wine with a strong odor, which is between new and old; and it should be prescribed that he eat a little food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And put on his food feathers, and birds, that is, many pigeons; and let him eat pigeon-feathers.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it should be that the drink of bloodletting and phlebotomy is more than food; and it should be given in a drink to some men at the hour of the tarragon, or a remedy with musk, that is, muscatel, or alsecaine before bloodletting: and before phlebotomy, or after: so that the principal members are comforted, and the blood is made subtile.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it should not be that they take it in a hot drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	On Bloodletting Without Scarring.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	But those bloodletting that are without scarring are those that are laid on the liver, and the spleen, and the bladder, and the navel, and places of the testicles, and the stomach-ach: because these members do not suffer scarring on themselves.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And it is not sought through them, except by an attack of blood from one member to another: such as we put the Bloodletting on the breasts in the sickness of the flow of blood to the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them, that we may relieve a member from cold bloodletting that is in a member: such as we put the Bloodletting on the stomach, and the navel.
